subject: Fashion
title: Child Labor in Fashion
description: A quick win: understand Child Labor in Fashion.

hook.text: An estimated 160 million children worldwide work instead of attending school. Many pick our cotton.

buildup.text: In Uzbekistan, children were forced into cotton fields every harvest season for decades by the state.

discovery.text: Child labor hides in subcontracting layers. Brands audit the main factory but not the farm.

twist.text: International pressure ended Uzbekistan's program, but child labor just moved to less monitored regions.

climax.text: Every layer of outsourcing adds a shadow where exploitation can hide, far from any brand's audit trail.

punchline.text: Out of sight, out of audit, still in the supply chain.

quiz.question: Why is child labor difficult to detect in fashion supply chains?
options: Children work in countries that don't allow foreign auditors
Brand audits typically cover only the main factory, not farms or subcontractors deeper in the chain
Child workers are deliberately trained to hide from inspectors
